ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I expanded my knowledge of the Spanish language, specifically within the context of the medical profession. Professor Carreras's thorough lectures provided deep insights into several different diseases and disorders that we may very well encounter in the medical profession and the appropriate language to address each situation.
How to talk about medical topics in Spanish!
I learned many different medical terms in Spanish; it was very interesting.
Improved language skills.
Lots of medical topics (some of which I didn't know even in English lol) and Spanish-speaking skills
Espaol perfecto.
We learned a great deal about different sectors of medicine from mental health to diabetes.
I learned about different medical disorders, their symptoms, and how to treat them.
I really built a vocabulary in medical Spanish this semester.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lectures were definitely the highlight of the class. Each lecture provided an in-depth overview of various medical conditions and the relevant terminology. I think the main area for improvement is creating more spaces for peer interactions. The class centered heavily around listening to presentations and watching relevant videos, and it would be great if there were more opportunities for students to work together and practice speaking Spanish with each other.

One of the strengths was that Professor Carreras made sure to keep the class engaging. I just wish there had been more set time during class for discussion, as opposed to just commenting on the material being presented.

Strengths: Professor is super caring and great and encourages participation
Weaknesses: Sometimes lecture can get a little boring
Slightly unorganized Canvas wise but overall amazing course.

Strengths: Mercedes is unbelievably nice and the class is super chill
Weaknesses: Almost zero feedback given the entire semester
Aprendes muchsimo.

the strengths are definitely the course content and the professor. I really thought the class was super engaging and i enjoyed the professors way of teaching. In terms of weaknesses, it was a bit difficult to gauge my status in the class since we did not receive many grades during the semester, therefore, it was a bit difficult to see where I could improve my spanish at times.

Strengths: The professor is a gem!! She is really enthusiastic about the class and tried to make it as fun as possible on Zoom. The class size was also very nice and allowed for better engagement. Weaknesses: The class was a little disorganized and the syllabus was confusing. Also there was little feedback given on our work so it was hard to gauge how we were doing in the class. For the future, I would recommend making the syllabus more clear and consistent with Canvas as well as giving feedback on our writing and having office hours for more personal help.
Really helpful readings and opportunities to hone writing. However, grades could have been turned in in a more timely manner.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I think the lecture format worked out very well; students were able to engage with the class and discuss various concepts with the professor throughout the course. 
In terms of areas that could be improved, I have two suggestions. Firstly, I think it would be helpful if the homework assignments were timed such that the material covered on the homework is covered at approximately the same time in class; this would allow for a bit more consistency in class. We also did an exercise with breakout rooms once during the semester, and it was a great opportunity to get to know other classmates and have peer conversations in Spanish outside of our class discussions. I would suggest doing more breakout rooms if the class continues in a virtual format, or else allowing for a bit more peer interactions in a live format so that classmates can build a rapport amongst themselves. 
It would also be very helpful if feedback on homework assignments was provided at more regular intervals throughout the semester so that students can constantly gauge their success in the class and make adjustments where necessary.
I liked that we had some asynchronous days!
I really enjoyed the live virtual lecture format
Online discussions in Zoom worked well given the circumstances.
In any language class, Zoom is going to be especially hard, but I think this class handled discussions about as well as it could.
Everything worked.
This class was phenomenal in adapting to the pandemic format. Asynchronous days were an excellent adjustment and outlet to responding to zoom fatigue.
The use of the presentations was helpful with the material but made it hard to participate in the class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course for anyone looking for an encouraging environment to improve their Spanish-speaking skills, especially within a medical context.
Yes, the class is engaging, and you learn about a wide variety of topics!
Yes absolutely!
Yes its great for language.

Yes, definitely! If you're looking for a chill L5 in Spanish, look no further, this is it. I got the sense that there were a lot of pre-med/more medically knowledged people in the class, but that didn't take anything away from my experience. Honestly above all else just take this class for Mercedes cause she is really awesome, it was a joy to go to class :). But if you're looking for a place to rigorously improve your Spanish, there are definitely better options out there - we never really had to talk (although most people did), a fair amount of the podcasts/videos were in English, and we got no feedback whatsoever on our written responses (except for one which was graded much more harshly than the others ultimately were) until reading period. The work is very chill, and I do think I improved my speaking and writing quite a bit, but that might just mean I was really rusty going into it. There isn't really a way to do the work faster or slower - it just is what it is, not bad at all but takes up a small chunk of time even when you don't have a small chunk of time to spare. But I found it overall to be a really fun and enjoyable class and would certainly recommend shopping it to everyone in the hope that you get into the 18 student enrollment cap (so if you want the L5 you do need to have a backup plan).
Of course! Take it.

Yes, the professor is amazing!! She is truly a gem and facilitated really great discussions on the complexity of medicine and public health issues in general. I think in-person class would be a bajillion times better for engagement and the overall flow of the class.
Yes especially for students looking to hone their medical skills and use of language.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had some asynchronous days as well.
Nothing else.
There were lecture aspects of the course as well.
